title: Antoine Bailly
text:
Antoine Bailly (4 July 1944 – 26 June 2021) was a French-born Swiss geographer. He worked as a professor of geography in France, Canada, and Switzerland. He held a doctoral degree from <a href="Paris-Sorbonne%20University">Paris-Sorbonne University</a>, as well as degrees from the <a href="University%20of%20Pennsylvania">University of Pennsylvania</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Franche-Comt%C3%A9">University of Franche-Comté</a>.
Biography.
Bailly was the co-author of over 30 books and more than 300 articles in the fields of geography and regional science. He drew inspiration from <a href="Walter%20Isard">Walter Isard</a>, <a href="Peter%20Gould%20%28geographer%29">Peter Gould</a>, and and was one of the pioneers of geographical representation and regional medicometrics. He was a co-founder of the École suisse de nouvelle géographie alongside <a href="Jean-Bernard%20Racine">Jean-Bernard Racine</a> and Claval.
Bailly received the Founder's Medal from the <a href="Regional%20Science%20Association%20International">Regional Science Association International</a>, the highest distinction in regional science, in 2008. On 6 October 2011, he was awarded the <a href="Vautrin%20Lud%20Prize">Vautrin Lud Prize</a> as part of the . He was given a doctor honoris causa from <a href="Alexandru%20Ioan%20Cuza%20University">Alexandru Ioan Cuza University</a>, the <a href="University%20of%20Lisbon">University of Lisbon</a>, the <a href="Universit%C3%A9%20du%20Qu%C3%A9bec">Université du Québec</a>, and the <a href="Hungarian%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">Hungarian Academy of Sciences</a>. In 2000, he was made a Knight of the <a href="Ordre%20national%20du%20M%C3%A9rite">Ordre national du Mérite</a>. In 2021, he was nominated for membership into the <a href="Lisbon%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">Lisbon Academy of Sciences</a>.
Antoine Bailly died on 26 June 2021 at the age of 76.
